Binary Searching Algorithm

In this tutorial, we will learn about how linear searching algorithm works. Also, we will implement this binary search algorithm in programming languages like C, C++, Python and Java.

Binary Search is a searching algorithm for determining the position of an element in a sorted array.

Overview

  • It is a very efficient algorithm.
  • This search method searches the given item with the fewest possible comparisons.
  • To begin the binary search, we must first sort the array of elements.
  • The logic behind this technique is given below. 
    • Find the mid element of the array.
    • Compare the middle element with an item.
    • There are three cases:
      • If it is the desired element then a search is successful,
      • If it is less than the desired item then search only in the first half of the array.
      •  If it is greater than the desired item, search in the second half of the array.
    • Repeat the same steps until an element is found.

Requirements

  • The list must be ordered.
  • Rapid random access is required, so we cannot use binary search for a linked list.

Algorithm

Given an array k of n elements in search order, find value x.

  • Initialize as follows: low=0, high=n-1
  • Perform Search: Step 4 should be repeated while low <= high.
  • Determine the index of the interval’s midpoint: mid=(low + high)/2
  • Compare:
    • If X < k[mid], then high=mid-1.
    • If X > k[mid], then low=mid + 1.
    • Else write(“The search was successful”)
    • Return (mid)
  • Search is Unsuccessful
    • Return
  • Exit

Python, Java Examples (Recursive Approach)

#python examples


def binarySearch(arr, x, low, high):

    if high >= low:

        mid = low + (high - low)//2


        if arr[mid] == x:
            return mid


        elif arr[mid] > x:
            return binarySearch(arr, x, low, mid-1)


        else:
            return binarySearch(arr, x, mid + 1, high)

    else:
        return -1


arr = [3, 4, 5, 6, 7, 8, 9]
x = 4 //element to be searched

result = binarySearch(arr, x, 0, len(arr)-1)

if result != -1:
    print("Element is present at index " + str(result))
else:
    print("Not found")
// Java Examples

class BinarySearch {
  int binarySearch(int arr[], int x, int low, int high) {

    if (high >= low) {
      int mid = low + (high - low) / 2;

     
      if (arr[mid] == x)
        return mid;


      if (arr[mid] > x)
        return binarySearch(arr, x, low, mid - 1);

      // Search the right half
      return binarySearch(arr, x, mid + 1, high);
    }

    return -1;
  }

  public static void main(String args[]) {
    BinarySearch ob = new BinarySearch();
    int arr[] = { 3, 4, 5, 6, 7, 8, 9 };
    int n = arr.length;
    int x = 4;
    int result = ob.binarySearch(arr, x, 0, n - 1);
    if (result == -1)
      System.out.println("Not found");
    else
      System.out.println("Element found at index " + result);
  }
}

Binary Searching Algorithm Complexity

Time Complexity

  • Best case complexity: O(1)
  • Average case complexity: O(logn)
  • Worst case complexity: O(logn)

Space Complexity

The space complexity of the binary search is O(1).

Binary Search Applications

  • Binary Search is the conventional search algorithm of google.
  • Useful for the indexing in database systems.
